title: Modeling a Non-Periodic Context - Quadratic Function

content.question: Part A (i) Use the given data to write three equations that can be used to find the values for constants <math alttext="a"><mi>a</mi></math>, <math alttext="b"><mi>b</mi></math>, and <math alttext="c"><mi>c</mi></math> in the expression for <math alttext="I open parentheses t close parentheses"><mi>I</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced></math>. (ii) Find the values for <math alttext="a"><mi>a</mi></math>, <math alttext="b"><mi>b</mi></math>, and <math alttext="c"><mi>c</mi></math> as decimal approximations.

frqParts.text: Part A (i) Use the given data to write three equations that can be used to find the values for constants <math alttext="a"><mi>a</mi></math>, <math alttext="b"><mi>b</mi></math>, and <math alttext="c"><mi>c</mi></math> in the expression for <math alttext="I open parentheses t close parentheses"><mi>I</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced></math>. (ii) Find the values for <math alttext="a"><mi>a</mi></math>, <math alttext="b"><mi>b</mi></math>, and <math alttext="c"><mi>c</mi></math> as decimal approximations.

Part B (i) Use the given data to find the average rate of change of the number of ice cream cones sold, in cones per day, from <math alttext="t equals 35"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>35</mn></math> to <math alttext="t equals 45"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>45</mn></math> days. Express your answer as a decimal approximation. Show the computations that lead to your answer. (ii) Use the average rate of change found in part B (i) to estimate the number of ice cream cones sold on day <math alttext="t equals 40"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>40</mn></math>. Show the work that leads to your answer. (iii) Compare the estimate found in part B (ii) to the value given by the model, <math alttext="I open parentheses 40 close parentheses"><mi>I</mi><mfenced><mn>40</mn></mfenced></math>. Using characteristics of the average rate of change and characteristics of the quadratic model, explain why the two estimates differ. Your explanation should include a reference to the graph of \(I\).
Part C Explain how the range values of the function <math alttext="I"><mi>I</mi></math> should be limited by the context of the problem.

topic.text: 1.3: Rates of Change in Linear and Quadratic Functions

skill.text: Skill 1.B: Express functions, equations, or expressions in analytically equivalent forms that are useful in a given mathematical or applied context.
